And what about the high school boys, who surely stood up to say that they love boobies too.  Ha ha ha snicker snicker.   It's insulting and in extremely bad taste.  IMHO    Janice

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 05:25AM jteach wrote: Judy, Please listen to these very wise women!!!!!  I spent months and months after many surgeries and chemo crying.  anytime, anywhere.  Church, the grocery store, in my car.  I felt hopeless and alone, even with a good marriage and wonderful kids.  I've always been a genle soul, quiet and reserved, never asking for myself, but always giving.  Even when I got up the nerve to ask my onc for anti depressants (which I, too, always considered "crazy pills", or for the very weakest of people)  he poo pooed the idea, basically telling me to buck up.  I asked for advice here and was told to go to my PCP and to keep fighting for myself.  That was a real turning point for me.  I got over my embarrassment and went to my PCP, who completely understood and prescribed citalapram.  I became empowered on that very day. Ask for what you need.  Keep asking til you get what you need.  Become the woman that you always wanted to be.  GET THE CHEMO!!!!!!!!  You do not yet know your destiny, but there could be a future full of wonder and joy.  Please do not give up!!!!!! Keep us posted, please!  (((((HUGS)))))   Janice
Posts.Title: Deciding Against Chemo JudyAnnW Titan

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2011 06:52AM jteach wrote: Ladies,  I am sorry that most of you have experienced this worst kind of pain, but I have found comfort in your posts.  I have long wondered what in the world I ever did in life to deserve such a thoughtless and cold family.  I feel rejected and unloved by them.  If , God forbid, this were to happen to one of my daughters, I'd be there in a heartbeat.   What a wake up call this has been.  My husband and daughters were and are my rock.  I thank God for them.  But as for my parents and my brother, I will never get over the lack of care and respect I received from them.  It is their loss, too, though, as I will never engage in anything but light , meaningless conversation with them again.  They hurt my heart. Janice

Posts.Content: May 13, 2011 03:44PM jteach wrote: My neuropathy was severe.  My doctor prescribed neurontin (gabapentin).   After a year and a half it is almost gone.  I also think it tries to keep my hotflashes at bay.   Good luck to you.    Janice
Posts.Title: Neuropathy Treatments glendag VickyC10

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2012 05:30PM jteach wrote: I'm almost afraid to post here, not just because I'm "only" IIb, but because it's such a sensitive subject.  But the thread evoked such a visceral reaction in me that I wanted to add my two cents anyway. I feel like I have been through hell and back, and I will never, ever be the same both physically and emotionally.  I think I'll just speak for myself, and I'm ashamed of this, but I've had 3 experience so far since my diagnosis almost 3 years ago where friends have come to me with the fear of having BC.  2 of them did not have it and the 3rd was very early stage.  I felt truly jealous.  I'm hoping that it's just human nature, but I had private meltdowns each time.  It's not that I wish bad on anyone, but it's more of a giant "why me?" God bless us all, no matter where we're at in this miserable circumstance.  (Hugs) to all.   Janice
Posts.Title: Why am I only ok talking to stage III ladies?feeling like a jerk Josiekat lkc

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 12:00PM - edited Apr 30, 2010 12:01PM by jteach Faith and Jaimieh, I had the exact same problems that Jaimieh has.  I even started a thread about it when it started because it hurt so bad and was so gross. I found that by squeezing that "ooze" out of my toes after bathing in a hot bath with epsom salts, the problem seemed to subside.  The clincher, though, was buying Earth shoes.  I'm still wearing them, because I've got that nail over nail thing still going on.   Anyway, the Earth shoes take the weight of your body OFF OF YOUR TOES!  I found this to be key in my own foot recovery.  The shoes have an inverted heel.  Your heel is lower than the ball of your foot and your toes.  Give them a try!  I really thought I'd never be able to walk without pain again until I found them! Good luck!   Janice
Posts.Title: Big toes -- OUCH!! Faith316 lorieg

Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 12:46PM jteach wrote: ghostie- I finished 6 wks of rads in March.  I am very fair skinned and burned badly under my arm.  I mean really badly.  I used Alra at the suggestion of one of our fellow sisters here and it was a miracle!  My skin literally went from purplish black to pink within 7 days.  I'll never be without it in my home again.  Best of luck to you! Janice
